title: List of ecclesiastical works by Alfred Waterhouse
data: Ince-in-Makerfield , Wigan , Greater Manchester 53°31′54″N 2°37′03″W / 53.5318°N 2.6176°W / 53.5318 ; -2.6176 ( Catholic Chapel , Ince Cemetery )
Roman Catholic chapel in stone with a slate roof . It is in Norman style , with a nave of four bays and a chancel apse
Ince-in-Makerfield , Wigan , Greater Manchester 53°31′56″N 2°37′02″W / 53.5323°N 2.6173°W / 53.5323 ; -2.6173 ( Anglican Chapel , Ince Cemetery )
Chapel in stone with a slate roof in Early English style , with a nave of three bays , a short chancel , a north porch , and a bellcote
West Norwood , Lambeth , Greater London 51°25′56″N 0°05′55″W / 51.4323°N 0.0986°W / 51.4323 ; -0.0986 ( Kershaw memorial , West Norwood )
Pink and grey granite memorial to James Kershaw
Brasted , Kent 51°16′47″N 0°06′15″E / 51.2796°N 0.1043°E / 51.2796 ; 0.1043 ( St Martin 's Church , Brasted )
A church with a core dating from the 13th century . Waterhouse restored it , largely rebuilt the exterior , and added a south chancel chapel and a north vestry
Brooklands , Sale , Greater Manchester 53°24′33″N 2°19′07″W / 53.4092°N 2.3187°W / 53.4092 ; -2.3187 ( St John 's Church , Brooklands )
Waterhouse 's first Anglican church , it is constructed in sandstone with a tiled roof in Gothic Revival style
Caversham , Reading , Berkshire 51°28′02″N 0°58′21″W / 51.4672°N 0.9724°W / 51.4672 ; -0.9724 ( West Memorial Hall , Caversham )

Built as a Baptist Free Church in red brick with blue brick decoration , a stone plinth and dressings , and a tiled roof . It is in Gothic Revival style , with a gable facing the road , and a stair turret on the right leading up to the gallery
Besses o ' th ' Barn , Bury , Greater Manchester 53°32′34″N 2°17′24″W / 53.5428°N 2.2900°W / 53.5428 ; -2.2900 ( Congregational Church , Besses o ' th ' Barn )
In red brick with yellow and blue brick decoration and slate roofs
Penmaenmawr , Conwy , Wales 53°16′13″N 3°55′06″W / 53.2703°N 3.9182°W / 53.2703 ; -3.9182 ( St Seiriol 's Church , Penmaenmawr )
A new church for English-speaking people in Early English style
Blackmoor , Selborne , Hampshire 51°05′46″N 0°53′12″W / 51.0961°N 0.8868°W / 51.0961 ; -0.8868 ( St Matthew 's Church , Blackmoor )
A new church for Roundell Palmer , 1st Earl of Selborne . It is constructed in stone , and is in Gothic Revival style
Stoke Newington , Hackney , Greater London 51°33′53″N 0°04′38″W / 51.5646°N 0.0773°W / 51.5646 ; -0.0773 ( Spreat Monument , Abney Park Cemetery )
Monument to John Spreat and his wife in three stages with a pyramidal cap
Eaton Hall , Cheshire 53°08′27″N 2°52′39″W / 53.1409°N 2.8776°W / 53.1409 ; -2.8776 ( Eaton Chapel , Cheshire )

A chapel for the 1st Duke of Westminster in sandstone with a slate roof . It has a tall free-standing six-stage clock tower with a pinnacled spire joined to the body of the chapel in the lower two stages . The tower contains a ring of 28 bells . Inside the chapel are mosaics designed by Frederic Shields
Blackmoor , Hampshire 51°05′46″N 0°53′14″W / 51.096°N 0.8871°W / 51.096 ; -0.8871 ( Lychgate and wall , Blackmoor )
These consist of a lychgate in Gothic style , a churchyard wall , and a shed
West Norwood , Lambeth , Greater London 51°25′56″N 0°05′55″W / 51.4323°N 0.0986°W / 51.4323 ; -0.0986 ( Elworthy memorial , West Norwood )
Celtic cross and graveslab to the memory of F. T. Elworthy
A Gothic -style church in brick with stone dressings and a tiled roof
Caversham , Reading , Berkshire 51°28′03″N 0°58′21″W / 51.4676°N 0.9726°W / 51.4676 ; -0.9726 ( Caversham Baptist Church )
A Gothic -style church in brick with stone dressings and a tiled roof . At the southwest corner is a two-stage tower
Bury , Greater Manchester 53°35′38″N 2°17′52″W / 53.5940°N 2.2977°W / 53.5940 ; -2.2977 ( Tomb chest , St Mary 's , Bury )
A tomb chest to the memory of John Slagg and members of his family
Constructed in knapped flint with red brick bands , stone dressings , and tiled roofs . The principal donor was Thomas Fairbairn
The first large-scale Gothic Revival church by Waterhouse . It is constructed in brick and has tiled roofs
Greater Manchester 53°31′53″N 2°16′08″W / 53.5313°N 2.2689°W / 53.5313 ; -2.2689 ( Heaton Park Congregational Church )
Built in brick with slate roofs , in Gothic Revival style . It has since been converted into apartments . Buildings of England Manchester specifically give G.T . Redmayne as the architect
Stanstead Abbots , Hertfordshire 51°47′27″N 0°00′34″E / 51.7908°N 0.0094°E / 51.7908 ; 0.0094 ( St Andrew , Stanstead Abbots )

Designed for T. F. Buxton of Easneye , this is a new church in Perpendicular style . Herttfordshire Pevsner 2019 claims Zephaniah King as the architect , Historic England says it was Waterhouse . It is a cruciform church with a southwest tower , faced in knapped flint with stone dressings and tiled roofs . The gates and gatepiers to the churchyard , together with the railings and a drinking fountain are listed at Grade II
intro: Alfred Waterhouse (1830-1905) was a prolific English architect who worked in the second half of the 19th century. His buildings were largely in Victorian Gothic Revival style. Waterhouse's biographer, Colin Cunningham, states that between about 1865 and about 1885 he was the most widely employed British architect. He worked in many fields, designing commercial, public, educational, domestic, and ecclesiastical buildings. Waterhouse was born in Liverpool of Quaker parents. After being articled to Richard Lane in Manchester, he took a ten-month tour of the Continent, then established his own practice in Manchester. Many of his early commissions came from Quakers and other nonconformist patrons. He came to national recognition when he won a competition for the design of Manchester assize courts. His next major public commissions in Manchester were for Strangeways Gaol and Manchester Town Hall. In 1865 he opened an office in London, which was followed by his first major commission in London, the Natural History Museum. Meanwhile, he was also designing country houses. Here his major work was the rebuilding of Eaton Hall in Cheshire for the 1st Duke of Westminster, which was the most expensive country house of the [19th] century.
